If you are looking for a shinning example of what Hollywood considers to be thought provoking film as art this just about covers it.  I couldn't keep track of the number of people killed, but two dogs were killed and some kind of an antelope or something was shot.  All the cats lived, but then they would.  Stereotype of what Hollywood considers Texas to be?  Check.  Pointless Violence?  Check.  Good guys don't win?  Check.  Bad guys don't win?  Check.  Life is meaningless?  Check.  No point to this plot?  Check.  In fact, the only thing missing on the Hollywood Epic Film list was senseless sex and they are probably saving that for the sequel.

You have to be intelligent, literate, and alert to enjoy a deep film like this. Most people who are regular shallow losers can't understand Coen films. The character played by Javier Bardem makes this movie well worth watching. But if you're dull and braindead, don't bother.

I liked this a lot, very engaging with good acting and put together well.  There was a point, however, where the violence did start to seem excessive, almost pornographic.  I think it was when the hit man goes to the office and takes out the guy behind the desk.  At that point my enthusiasm went down a notch.  By this stage of the movie it started to seem more like a collection of murder scenes strung together with some story thrown in for good measure.  Still, I highly recommend it to anyone that likes crime dramas but who can also stomach the murderous adventures of a psychopath that kills people with less emotion than we might have for a swatted  fly.

Casting is great; but the movie is just plain stupid.

You're still hoping for Josh Brolin's character to make it, even though his fate is pretty much handed to him.

This movie was fascinating but unsatisfying because the viewer can't justifiably root for any character.  Llewelyn Moss (played by Josh Brolin) garners some sympathy for his suffering while evading a ruthless killer, but his fate is predictable after he steals $2 million in drug money.  Tommy Lee Jones as Sheriff Bell fights the good fight as he pursues hit man Anton Chigurh (played by Javier Bardem), but Bell seems bland and passionless while the crime network grows increasingly out of control.  Javier Bardem is incredible as Anton; you cant look away from his pale unlined face, strangely perfect haircut and obsession with cleanliness as he commits murders and gets shot.  Bardem deserved the Academy Award for Best Supporting Actor (why not Best Leading Actor?), but I wish some rationale was offered for the characters sadistic behavior.

Maybe the whole point was to not have a plot based on the usual good vs. evil theme.  The plot is as stark as the Texas desert landscape in panoramic view at the beginning of the movie.  If you can stop looking for meaning in the unresolved and immoral corruption, youll appreciate the film, but might have that what just happened? feeling at the end.

This movie was about as anticlimactic as they come, almost as if the writer thought it would be clever to do something dumb. The movie focuses on a hunter trying to avoid getting killed while carrying around a case of cash.....for the first hour and a half. At first we're led to believe the hunter is quite resourceful, skilledd and intelligent. In other words the bad guys have met their match. Heck, at first we're led to believe it will go 'somewhere'.

After that first hour and a half the movie completely flatlines, by design obviously. Your expectations for the hunter fall completely flat. Where the money went isn't answered. Main antagonist gets hurt in a random car accident.....your like...um...ok? It then ends with retiring police guy that he had a couple of dreams I'm guessing were to interpret, reaching for some sort of deep meaning. Well they're dreams. People over analyze dreams as it is. Who cares.

It had so much potential. It blows a lot of steam but in the end it leaves you hoping for something more, it leaves feeling empty, soulless; hoping for a resolution of the conflict, mainly the bad guy to get what he's got coming, deservedly so. Any movie with Tommy Lee Jones in it I'm watching. The acting was phenomenal. The Texas desert setting was different, barren, with the potential to be a great snoozer, yet the combination of fine raw acting and a well written suspenseful script the film becomes alluring, it draws you into the movie.
This flick has everything we hate about life, mainly its injustices. A sheriff and his staff who spend the entire film looking and chasing for the bad guy(s) but quite never get their hands on him (them), either through unheard of incompetence or bad luck. A hard working guy, apparently, who catches the break of his life by stumbling upon a load of cash, lots of it. The kind of hard, cold-cash we all secretly hope to have the fortune drops on our "laps" some random day as we go about our business. A beloved wife, young and beautiful, with whom to grow old, with a full life ahead who's a couple of breaks away from having her life changed for the better but ends up grieving her loss. A bad guy, a psychopath, the kind you hope burns in a thousand hells over, yet keeps catching break after break to see another day and escape capture--I kept hoping he'd end up somehow in the bottom of a wood-chipper.
 Yep, the film has a lot of the real life, the life we'd all hate if it happened to us. Don't expect to feel cheery or have your spirits uplifted after watching this flick. But iff horrid, sad, truncated stories you're in, but all means watch.

I watched this film not long after it came out, and didn't care for it. Ten years later, having matured in my pursuit of great films to watch, I can't rave over this film enough. The Coen brothers are a mixed bag for some people, but in every detail, they appeal to what I want to see in film. The cinematography is tremendous - wide open desert shots with a flat lens, the Rembrandt lighting effect across faces in a dark room, the shock of riding inside a car that is sideswiped, and even pools of blood have "character" in this film (watch closely and you'll notice pools of blood are treated distinctly by each character). The casting was perfect from top to bottom, and my favorite aspect of the Coens - the dialogue. At times, you're not sure whether a character is trying to make you laugh in a sick, twisted way, or if that's truly how the person thinks within their own malaise of self-delusion. This last point is where most viewers disconnect from the Coens. This is not a film to watch idly - every word must be heard and understood for the message to be received by the audience. Furthermore, the dialogue and pace intensifies as the film reaches its zenith, only to end in Shakespearean tragedy and lamentation. For once the Academy got it right - "No Country for Old Men" deserved all the accolades it received, hands down.

I do love this movie.  I have seen it a few times and also read the book.
Watching it this time, I was surprised to see that an important character was completely left out of this version, which steals a lot of impact from the last scene of Chigur with the young wife.
In the book, Moss goes to San Antonio to negotiate a deal with the guy that this movie does not identify but is shown in his high rise office in a meeting with the character played by Woody Harrelson.  Moss goes to see this guy in the 14th floor office (which is really on the 13th floor because tall buildings traditionally do not have 13th floors (that's the joke in the scene with Harrelson), but is told that there is no way to call off Chigur, because Chigur is not working for the guy in San Antonio. Moss then buys a car in San Antonio to drive to El Paso and meet the wife.
On the way to El Paso, Moss sees a young woman trying to hitch a ride.  (There is a version of this movie that has the girl in the movie, but the one that I just watched, does not), and picks her up.  They stop at a fancy motel between Fort Stockton and El Paso.  Moss gets a room with double beds and, after dinner, he puts the girl in one of the beds and he goes to sleep on the other.  That's where the Mexican gang caught up with him and killed him and the girl, in the same room.
So, when the Sheriff (of Terrell County) catches up with him, the place is already a crime scene and Sheriff Bell (Tommy Lee Jones) has to tell the wife that her husband was killed in a room with a young girl.  I have not seen any version of this movie that has the Sheriff telling the young wife that her husband was with a girl when he was killed, but that is in the book.
Now, in the book, when Chigur comes to kill the wife (and he does kill her), she is already believing that her husband ran off with a younger girl and got killed.  When she meets Chigur, he tells her that he (Chigur) made a deal with her husband that is the cause of her deatj.  She takes that to mean that her husband has paid Chigur to kill her and says, "But he's dead.  So, you don't have to do that."
Chigur says, "I made a promise" and then shoots her.

If you you don't like to think and instead prefer to be spoon fed, this movie might not be for you.  Maybe you would be more interested in the latest action flick with glamorous computer graphics and the same plot as those that came before it.

This movie begs a sequel even though some found the huge number of "you imagine what happened" peppered throughout the movie enough to call it good. In my opinion it damaged the films credibility.

First, If I come upon money of that magnitude, I am not taking a case and I would search the money, but being retired military its in my nature to be suspicious of everything, not to the point of paranoia though. When the guy took the case I simply shook my head as I knew what was going to happen and that ruined the movie from the start. I would not bring water back to a drug dealer and likely I would have done something else that is not too kind to the lone survivor of the drug gang immediately.

The only reason for the 4 stars was the acting, it was very decent, even if the actors did too many stupid things the writers created. Too many people saw and should have known who the hitman was. It appears the brothers that made this movie figured everyone was brain dead pacifists that trust everyone and question nothing.

I am sorry but someone that looks like that hitman is crying to be shot on sight. Walk to my truck carrying that cattle killer and you might make 2 steps before I dropped you, and I am a very, very good shot under pressure. Ask a stupid question, Flip a coin with dead eyes, again, you are dead. The actor did a great job making me hate him and everyone that was stupid enough to not recognize a killer. A big plus for the brothers
directing.

I dislike movies that telegraph what they are about from the first scene and leave too many cliffhangers in the movie.

The ending as I think it should have been done.

The brothers change nothing except for one scene......The car at the intersection still hits the killer, as the scene pulls back slightly the police officer jones, going to finalize some retirement paperwork pulls into that same intersection at the same moment witnessing the impact but not seeing who the victims are. Still carrying his sidearm and in uniform he rushes to the civilians car, and then turns to look at the other car just as our killer steps out....their eyes meet, the killer dives to the floorboard to retrieve his gun, at the same time Jones, recognizing who it is ducks and runs around the killers car. The killer then gets up, out of the car, still slightly dazed he looks, sees nothing, but hears a round being chambered behind him, the killer ducks slightly and spins firing slightly off mark....Jones's character does not miss, putting two into the chest of the killer....scene slowly pulls back, fade....credits.

I was surprised to find I hadn't reviewed this movie yet, despite it being my absolute favorite film outside of my predominant genres of sci-fi/fantasy/horror. I'm apparently developing a new appreciation for lit-fic the older I get, which is great because there's much to appreciate in films like this. Real life. Southwest. Gritty. I lived in Phoenix for 15 years (and miss it) which may account for my enjoyment of the film. I've watched it a half dozen times already since "discovering" it last year. Late, I know. I was late to Cormac McCarthy as well, having read The Road in 2012 which led to his other books. I didn't appreciate his bizarre writing style at first, but now I enjoy it. I have this film and the paperback sitting on my shelf next to the same pair for The Road. Which, despite the Pulitzer, is an inferior story to this one IMO. But that's okay because No Country the film won the Oscars while The Road the book won the Pulitzer, flip-flop. This is not a tough decision, especially for the price.

Awesome movie. The acting and cinematography are both great. The plot is there, but the themes and characters are the most important. Keep in mind that the plot about the drug money s not the main point. It's about an old man struggling to come to terms with a world that he feels is changing for the worse.

Don't listen to the dumb yahoo's that are giving this a negative rating because most of them are clueless. The very title of the movie tells you who the movie is about. Sadly, people have grown too accustomed to the typical Hollywood film structure and so they expected some kind of big showdown at the end. There are plenty of other generic thrillers for that.

This film certainly isn't for everyone, but it is an excellent film that is likely to go down as a classic for many years to come. The strongest part of the film is easily Javier Bardem and it is no surprise that he won an Oscar for his performance. The film flows very smoothly and keeps your attention throughout the entire movie.
Obviously the Coen brothers have a terrific track record with their films, and for as great as all of their films are this one is likely the best. It's dark and suspenseful and keeps you on the edge of your seat.
If your looking for comedy or a lot of action this isn't the film to watch. There is some action in the film but it certainly isn't jam packed full of heroes and villains going at each other's throats. Instead, this film uses intimate scenes between great actors to convey its story. Everyone should see this movie at some point even if some people might find it to be a little "boring", because this is just a really well putt together film.

Worse ending in the history of films.. you don't get to see the main character's final action scene.. you have some psycho who's go to weapon is an oxygen tank and hose.. apparently he hasn't heard of a gun with a silencer. main villain gets hit by a car from out of nowhere and just walks off... what really upsets me is that i will never get the time i spent watching this film back in my life.

great acting, truly amazing; casting was beyond excellent; dialogue was wonderful; cinematography was splendid. but the film, itself, is hollow: if there is no meaning to life, there is no meaning to art; it's just a brief diversion. the film is dazzling in many ways but it has no statement to make, nothing to tell its viewers (that is a strong indictment of the filmmakers, who, for all their talent, are empty); nihilism is not a message, it's a cheat, an evasion; the filmmakers should learn about their ancestors, their heritage, then, re-read aristotle.

A good expression of what life could be, what it is, and how it was, in regards to gang/cartel/illegal drug dealing life and it's influences, and more generally, the battle between your/society's demons (crippling fear in the face of evil, greed, etc.). I appreciate how this movie depicted an alternative timeline compared to the typical, "...and the featured protagonist wins in the end" story arch that is often expressed. I like experiencing both sides of the same coin to get a more balanced perspective on life.

The movie captures the spirit of the book, perhaps more accurately than any other adaption of a novel to date. Bardem's portrayal of the psychopathic killer Anton Chigurh is astonishing, and truly unforgettable. In fact, it is so powerful that it may obscure the true message of the movie: which is the reality of a drug war so horrific that any steps to end the carnage and human degradation should be immediately implemented. The rest of the cast is equally good--Tommy Lee Jones is the definitive Texas sheriff--and the cinematography is flawless. The Coen brothers once again demonstrate their understanding of the big screen--and the importance of story telling.

A brooding, at times violent, dramatic tale of a drug deal gone wrong in the desert in western Texas.  Xavier Bardes plays the psychopath who's role is to track down the missing money, and plays it brilliantly... one of the most malevolent characterizations outside of the sick/horror genre.  Josh Brolin is more acceptable by equally brilliant as the hapless cowboy that comes across the drug deal scene, takes the money, and remains optimistic to the end that he can outrun the baddies; but is wrong.  Woody Harrelson plays a cock-sure bounty hunter hired to track down the money, and is effective in the role but not as stellar as others in the cast.  Pride of place goes to Tommy Lee Jones, the weather-beaten, aging Sheriff who's seen it all before, can't clean it up, but survives into retirement to wonder what's happening to the World.  His character matches the landscape: hard, sun-bleached, and wise with the passage of eons.  The film is a gripping, dusty and believable drama played out in the beautiful and unforgiving wilderness close to the Texas / Mexico border.

I can't resist a Coen brothers movie and this one is a masterpiece of technique. It contains little dialogue in the first hour yet builds a powerful narrative. The setting is Texas in the late 1970s when drug running across the border was bigger and bloodier business than it is today. Josh Brolin plays a down and out former Vietnam veteran who stumbles upon a drug deal gone bad and makes off with a lot of money. The bad guys send a mercenary played by Javier Bardem to recover their funds. Tommy Lee Jones plays an aging sheriff unsettled by the new reality of the drug running culture, hence the title.

It was an excellent movie, but be forewarned: it is a dark story with an unsatisfying ending. It was nominated for several Academy Awards. The source material is from a novel by Cormac McCarthy, whose work is dark and dystopian. I've not read this or any of the author's books. If you are a Coen brothers fan, this one is not to be missed.

Insanely overrated film. Great cinematography and good acting. Absolutely horrible story, not to mention it's entirely pointless. Most things in the movie don't make sense, are contrived, or completely arbitrary. Josh Brolin's character finds a bunch of money but doesn't seem sure if he's safe to stick close to home or hide somewhere far away. He actually returns to the scene of the crime to give one of the drug dealers water shortly after taking a large sum of money. Why would he do this? 1. This is the scene of a drug deal gone wrong and he has no idea if he's going to run into the bad guys, and what do you know, he does, coincidentally at the exact same time he chose to go back for no good reason because he's trying to give water to a guy that is already dead and puts himself at risk of getting caught or worse. 2. This is now a crime scene, so he not only risks the chance of running into the bad guys but also cops. 3. He just retrieved a large amount of money, why on earth would he ever go back to the very spot where he took the money? All he had to do was take the money and his wife out of town for a little while and there's absolutely no way anyone involved in the drug deal would find him because no one saw him take the money and the tracker would be out of range. There's not much Brolin's character does the whole movie that makes sense. He's even prepared to go up against Chigurh when all he had to do was flee with the money and remain low key. Which is actually what he kind of does but Chigurh still manages to easily find him for some reason. Now Brolin got his wife involved and finds there's no easy way out, when all along he's basically the one who put himself in this predicament because almost everything he does is stupid and detrimental to his safety.

He only finds there's a tracker in the money after a while staying in motels. But yet he seems paranoid that someone is after him even before that. This is set in 1980 right? They don't have the technology to find exactly where he is at all times. You're telling me Chigurh can find exactly where he is based on an extremely outdated beeping tracker? Across the huge state of Texas, across all those cities and even down to the Mexican border? There's no way. There is no way Chigurh would've found him, especially at such long distances like all the way down to Mexico. Not only that but Woody Harrelson's character is able to find Brolin at the drop of a hat and without explanation. Characters seem to be psychic and are able to find each other extremely quickly but the sheriff and his team can't track a killer who is leaving a trail of dead bodies in his wake. The movie certainly looks good and is well acted but the plot is too silly to take seriously. None of it makes sense when you stop to think about it. You're constantly left asking why the characters are doing what they're doing because none of it makes any sense. And we never really get to know any of the characters. Many of them come and go fairly quickly or are completely out of place with the actual plot of the movie and don't actually serve much purpose.

 I just don't get why so many people like this movie. Chigurh is a cool character yes, but he's completely reckless and leaves a trail of dead bodies wherever he goes. He isn't smart or even good at what he does because he just kills everyone he sees. He carjacks people. He blows up a car and steals drugs from behind the counter at a pharmecy in broad daylight. He walks around carrying a shotgun with a silencer on it in an open and exposed hotel lobby. He'd be picked up before the movie is over but no, instead Brolin who was lying pretty low the entire time is constantly able to be found when he doesn't even have a tracker on him anymore (not to mention the tracker only works for so long of a distance) and no one knows what he looks like. If the cops weren't so incompetent they'd have this case resolved in a short while, but instead they're useless. The movie sucks because the plot makes no sense. But I still give it two stars because it looks good and the actors are good. I understand this is based on a book but this won best screenplay. Are you kidding me? Best picture? One of the best movies of the 2000's? Please, not even close. I can understand liking a movie because of the way it makes you feel but a story that has so many plot holes, so little explanation for things, and basically no payoff or satisfying conclusion cannot be considered good. Basically the whole meaning and point of the movie is that there is no point. No Country For Old Men is a depressing experience and not in an emotional way but in a very cold way, and at the end of it all I guess that's what you really take away from it. The plot sucks but since it's wrapped up in a neat little package and the acting is good I guess people are fooled into thinking the movie is somehow deep and has a lot to say when it actually really doesn't. It just plods on and on, one pointless and nonsensical scene after the next, with long winded dialogue that sounds like it's written with the intention of sounding deep and profound. Not for me.

This was a riveting, tense, and awesome movie. The ending was kind of weird. It seems like they were just desperate to avoid having some kind of typical showdown ending, but maybe there's more to it than that. I think they definitely want me to think there's more to it than that, but it's not clear what. Is this, "The Treasure of the Sierra Madre"? Is it just about greed destroying people? Is it about violence? Corruption? Evil? It makes me think of all these things, but that doesn't mean it's saying anything about them. When you want to be liked, you're ambiguous. When you want to say something, you're clear. I'm inclined to think they're more interested in making me think they've said something profound than in actually saying something profound, but that's just the cynical position I've come to in life. Still. it was a riveting, excellent movie.

Hmm. I wrote the previous stuff without having read anything about the movie. It was just my opinion. I just read some more reviews, and they diminish the movie in my eyes. It still gets five stars because it's so awesome, but it appears I was wrong. It's not that the movie simply wants me to believe it's saying something profound. The Coen brothers apparently think they are delivering some first-rate philosophy with this movie. Not so. As I said before, they refuse to actually say anything. Unless you think they're saying that drugs fuel violence. Yeah, brilliant deduction Sherlock. Greed makes people do bad things? Also brilliant /s. Violence leads nowhere? What is this, a high-school philosophy essay on why violence is bad? In sum, I think the film-making is first rate. The philosophy and sociology are elementary.

This is as good as movies get. Bardem personifies the random badness of life and Jones the feeling of a good man "overmatched" by it. Josh Brolin is also great as a bystander who thinks he's in control of the situation. Beautiful, bleak shots of empty land. There is a lot of violence in the movie, much of it shocking even when you know it is coming: the Coens have the courage to show it without varnish. Think about the major movies you've seen in the past ten years. How many show violence for what it is: brutal, meaningless, destructive? It is one of my favorite Coen movies.

Well cast, acted, and shot.  Javier Bardem is a villain for the ages.  Cold and creepy, his performance equals and perhaps surpasses the classic suspense film chase villains:  Arnold's relentless Terminator, Yul Brynner's Gunslinger, Rutger Hauer's John Ryder (the Hitcher).  The cast (Tommy Lee Jones, Josh Brolin, Kelly Macdonald) and cinematography provide an authentic Texas feel, some of the film was indeed shot in Texas.  Gritty and unpredictable.

No Country For Old Men is a dumb, pointless, purposeless, UBER-overrated, overtly-graphic and mean-spirited movie from very overrated directors (Coen Brothers).  The cinematography is, admittedly, great and the movie is at least 'watcheable.'  The movie starts out well and seems very compelling for awhile...but goes downhill throughout and the story seems to be half-concocted: Why spoil the movie with the untimely, undramatic, and unimportant death Bardem's primary advesary -Josh Brolin?  Why not continue the duel between Javier Bardem and Josh Brolin leading to an epic and exciting showdown between the two at the end of the movie?

Tommy Lee Jones looks and seems washed up (not because he seems uninterested) and mumbles throughout the movie.  This is easily his worst performance I've ever seen.  Javier Bardem is detestable and extremely mean-spirited -whether he was intended to be that way or not.  He seems like an extremely dumb person and unlikeable person in real life who's acting skills are extremely-limited.  When he speaks dialog in No Country for Old Men he sounds like a quasi-retard with a low I.Q. This is probably the only type of role he could ever play, me-thinks.

The whole movie 'feels' completely devoid of purpose and completely 'dead.'  I do enjoy 'violent' movies, perhaps more than I should, but like many modern flics, N.C.F.O.M. seems like nothing more than an engine for an occasional pointless, violent and overtly graphic death of someone.  The lack of music throughout movie enhances the 'dead' ambience of the movie.  The fact that the public and 'critics' give a movie like this 'UNANIMOUS' high-ratings shows what an incredibly-stupid society it is that we live in.  1 1/2 stars.

I watched this because I had read descriptions of it as "the Coen brothers' masterpiece," and knew it had won Best Picture.  It doesn't deserve either accolade, IMHO.  Fargo is far more nuanced, and far less violent (though it has its moments).

Even as the villain's serial murders in No Country move more to the "just off screen" spot as the movie progresses, it was too much for me -- I get it already, he's a pitiless killer on a mission.  And for what?  After the long string of people he kills on the way to Josh Brolin's character, I found the handling of that death amazingly abrupt and pointless.

Both Fargo and No Country feature very fine acting and cracking dialogue, though I think Fargo has the edge on both fronts.  The villains are entirely different in the two movies, and while Javier Bardem is brilliant in No Country, the calm, pathological killer is just not something I enjoy much; if you do, this movie is worth watching for his performance alone.

Perhaps most important, Tommy Lee Jones' character in No Country is just too one-dimensional; I have now read that his backstory is one of the few major pieces they cut in adapting the book.  It really shows; I wanted far more than what I got.

The Coen Brothers hit the mark with this cinematic gem. A dark neo-western set in 1980 Texas, the film holds true to the Cormac McCarthy novel where a Vietnam Veteran (Moss) stumbles upon a drug deal gone bad and appropriates $2M for himself from the scene. It quickly progresses into cat-and-mouse chase between Moss, a psychopathic hit man hired to retrieve the money, and a local sheriff determined to protect Moss. A very well made thriller that explores the themes of depravity and fate. One of my top-5 favorite movies.

This is the first time I had seen this movie since just after its' theatrical release.  I was so impressed then, I dragged a couple of good friends with me to see it again a couple of weeks later.  I wondered now if it still held up after almost a decade.  It does.  Very well indeed.  Knowing the story, having seen it twice, it was a joy to savor the love and skills that went into this film by EVERYBODY associated with it.  And I mean everybody.  I suspect even the gaffers and the caterers cared.  The acting is stunning, the photography equally so.  The lighting, art.  Set design so spare and yet so totally real and amazing.  The sound.  Perfect.  This time I had stage buds in my ear with better than theater sound and what a difference.  Take a couple of hours in a quiet uninterrupted space and enjoy great art and love.  5 stars for everyone associated with this fun.

Anton Chigurh attempts to prove his flawed doctrine of Fatalism with a coin flip, but makes the philosophical error of forgetting that it was his CHOICE to perform the flip in the first place and it will still be his choice to pull or not pull the trigger regardless of the outcome.

Further demonstration of the inherent contradiction informing his life philosophy---- that made pretense of a superior way of being but reveals itself as mere psychosis--- is the way in which Chigurh tries to move through life as though he were unemotional and devoid of conscience, allthewhile operating by his own moral code. This is a man perpetually triggered, seething beneath the placid exterior. He has not disassociated himself from the afflictions of other mortals, just created his own, like the bright boy who has formulated his own language with which to converse inside his own head and share with no one.

Lucifer did envision to climb to the throne of God, as well, but his fall was no less spectacular than a calculated mercenary being plowed in traffic by an inattentive driver.

Lewelyn Moss, the manli-ess hombre to wear a feminine name since the boy named Sue, had to have been disappointed, were he able, at his "Plan B" outcome.

While this is not a "feel-good movie," two somewhat underrated aspects of this film are its social critique and its "MacGyver-ism."

The former is best exemplified in the scene, "What's Coming," toward the end of the film, when Sheriff Ed Tom Bell, played by the wryly stoic Tommy Lee Jones, sits down with another old boy and discusses the case. The old boy laments how "It's all about the money and the drugs...it's just g-d beyond everything. What's it mean? What's it leading to?"

After the other old boy speaks to the decline of the culture, Sheriff Bell replies, "I think once you stop hearing, 'Sir' and 'Ma'am' the rest is soon to foller." To which the other old boy replies, "Well, it's the tide. It's the dismal tide."

I think it's safe to say that tide has washed on shore like a tsunami.

I have watched this movie around five times, and each time it gets deeper. I think it is the very best Coen Bros. movie, and it does an outstanding job of translating a brilliant novel into a brilliant movie. It depicts a moment in time in the 1980s when this country became much more deeply and openly psychopathic than it was previously. Which is to say that this country has always been psychopathic in its ability to cause pain and suffering for economic gain: that is, after all, the essential story of the making of America.

Jones, Brolin, Bardem and Harrelson are at their best as the combatants; McDonald is poignant as the hapless and luckless wife. The landscape is unforgivingly bleak, the Mexicans are all dead, and the moral of the story is: you have to know when to get out of the game, because you simply aren't capable of winning against your opponents. The sheriff knows when to quit; Brolin and Harrelson's characters don't; and Anton Chigur is as indestructable, horrifying and inhuman as he is psychopathic. There really IS a lot of evil in the world...

The good:
--Good acting
--Good cinematography
The bad:
--Incoherent plot - too many unidentified people and groups involved
--Convenient coincidences - people just happen to show up at (in)convenient times
--Apparent clairvoyance - people just seem to know things that they couldn't possibly figure out
--Lazy ending - all loose ends
--Weak dialog.
--Zero character development - characters are cliches.
--Over-reliance on violent action.  In the 70s, filmmakers put in random car chases; in this movie it's random shootouts.
Bottom line:
The movie counterpart of an airport book.  Lots of violent action but not much else.  Good to kill time if you can watch it for free.

"A tale told by an idiot, full of sound and fury, signifying nothing." (Macbeth.) The character of Chigurh is as well developed as the character of the shark in Jaws.  In other words, he is nothing more than a mindless killer.  Unless you have a morbid fascination with people being brutally murdered, it's boring. There is no background as to how such an egregiously sociopathic individual as Chigurh may have developed, and why he was not 'weeded out' of society before this. Compare this to, for example, the Cody character in the classic White Heat where the pathological killer has a credible back-story - where the viewer can understand how such a monster could come to be.  The No Country plot is also flawed in other significant ways.  An all out, truck-assisted, fire fight in the streets of El Paso at night and nobody - either police or the typically well-armed residents of that west Texas city - wakes up or takes any interest?  Hard to believe.  The Carson Wells character is apparently a resourceful (he easily tracks down Moss in a Mexican hospital) former Army officer - possibly a former Special Forces officer.  He's in west Texas in the 1980s, therefore, he is almost certainly armed (probably, in his trade, heavily).  Yet he lets a homicidal maniac get the drop on him on a hotel stairway?  I don't think so.  If cornered, an armed former Special Forces officer would certainly attempt to drop, draw his weapon, and fire rather than face execution by a maniac.  Back to Chigurh: he exhibits the skills of an Army medic in treating his own wounds.  He knows exactly what implements and drugs to steal from the pharmacy.  This is not part of the usual skill set of a hit man.  Peculiar?  Seems he must have had some military experience.  Wells tells the fat cat in Houston (?) that he knows Chigurh - is that why?  Does he know him from the Viet Nam War?  Lastly, the absurd concept that a hit man, who has already done his job, would expose himself to capture  by seeking out and killing Moss' wife. (Note, strangely, no law men are watching Moss' wife who, for all they know, may be in possession of some or all of what all the other dead men were seeking.)  What about lawman Bell, the superannuated Wyatt Earp type?  A third generation cop who's been on the job too long and who is now disgusted by all the violence and the ever inventive ways criminals have of developing new forms of motivations for violence (i.e., circa 1980 drug deals).  Trite.  That story has been told a hundred times - much better.  In any case, the No Country plot is poorly constructed, full of 'cardboard' characters,' utterly unbelievable, and splattered with gratuitous violence...and gore.  A fine example of the Hollywood's sub-standard output and the unreliability of the self-congratulatory Academy Awards the Hollywood moguls give themselves.

It's an amazing film. I can't remember the last time a film affected me like this one. I had to buy it for the acting of Javier Bardem. What a friggin villain!! An unstoppable force who could manipulate reality and, apparently, put everyone else to sleep whenever he wanted to kill someone. It was like he would take his victims into some sort of alternate reality where there was no one else besides him and his victims. He was always so calm and never in a rush. He knew he had all the time he needed to kill his victims in that alternate reality so he was in no rush.

I don't want to spoil the film for those who have not seen it, but it's the type of film you have to watch over and over and over to catch subtle things you missed the first and even second time around. I was always captivated by the picture on the cover of the DVD. That villain looks like some sort of reincarnated cougar. An amazingly powerful dude.

This is all around a five star movie.  It is a gritty and violent crime drama.  Excellently told story. The characters are very well defined. The settings and details recreate perfectly the period of the film, which is pre cell phones 1980. Even the minor characters appear totally believable. The message of the movie rings true. In the world of organized crime, the violence used to enforce compliance is a never ending cycle, that consumes the criminals and spills over to affect innocent bystanders as well.
Cohen bros live up to their name.

Finally, an action movie with an original story and a particularly unique antagonist, Anton Chigur.  The movie follows the book very closely, which is a plus since I read the book first and really enjoyed it.  Pros: violent, realistic fighting scenes, chilling dialogue, and the general eerie feeling that makes your hair stand on end, and a villain who is so fascinating and original that you almost want to root for him.  Cons: a random, illogical, anti-climactic ending that is just as disappointing as the one in the book (hence the 4 stars)

It's similar to Fargo, but less broad in its humor and more polished in the level of direction and cinematography. The Coen brothers wanted the movie to succeed as a snap-shot of social dissolution along the Tex-Mex border circa 1980, especially the influence of Mexican drug cartels. Thus the Coens toned down regional accents and made the violence much grittier and less splashier. They also resisted the temptation to bring in yodeling music a la Raising Arizona. In fact, I believe there's no music in this movie until the end credits.

So, even though I miss all the usual gauche and Grand Guignol of the earlier Coen films, I think the restraint they show here--perhaps out of respect for their source material, a novel by one of the greatest living American writers--is meant as a token of respect and maybe a bid for posterity. The Coens are no longer young men; perhaps they want to be remembered as skilled craftsmen rather than sophomoric also-rans.

Bottom line: if you want an effective thriller that looks great on your Blu-ray entertainment system, you can't wrong with No Country For Old Men.

"No country for old men" is a Coen Brothers movie from a bleak novel by Cormac McCarthy.  A war veteran stumbles upon a drug deal gone bad and steals a large amount of money.  He could have gotten safely away, only he makes a poor choice and finds himself on the run from ruthless killers.  In particular one ruthless killer who represents fate and has his own rules that he abides by.
  As a cinematic exercise it is brilliant.  The camera work, pacing, acting are all stellar.
  As an artistic expression of a theme, it is very good, maybe great.  My compliant would be that it's a bit predictable, a bit overdone for those who have read similar novels, etc.  It's entirely likely, however, that I just didn't like the depressing theme
  Those who complain that the movie is great until the last thirty minutes are not wrong.  They were simply expecting a more traditional, less bleak movie, and they ignored/rejected/missed/whatever the early hints that it was not.  Lots of violence and depressing ideas.

This movie may divide viewers. It seems to appear that most people like it. However, I know some people who did not, and upon my first viewing, I did not like it at all. I even had trouble finishing it.
This film is very dark and disturbing. Do not let the high class casting and acting fool you. It can be bloody and very violent, visually. The story was alright, but the killer and the other characters are all very strange and uneven in their approach to things, so you never really know what to expect or to think about them.  Honestly, the Coen brothers are very talented, but believe it or not, they could have gotten a lot more impact without so much visual bravado. However, if they didn't I suppose it would not be a Coen brothers movie, then.
The visual style and cinematography are what really grab you from the start and never let you go. They really drive the film. The camera work is strong and vibrant. It truly keeps you watching until the end. The problem I have is that because the source material in this film is so dark and disturbing, and because the Coen brothers direct it so strikingly, you can't help but watch, or can't help but look away. The violence at times seems pointless and meaningless, and so do the character's story arcs, and their missions. This is what ruins it.
I do not have all bad things to say.
On to the good things.
The acting is some of the best you will see for the decade. All three main stars shine so much, it is hard to tell who is the best. They are spot on and brilliant. Javier Bardem really shines as a psychopathic killer. He is fun to watch. Josh Brolin, seems to be a bit of wild card. You never know what he will say or do next. Even watching it again, after all these years, he is still so entertaining because he is so unpredictable. Tommy Lee Jones seems to playing clueless at times, yet also all-knowing. I know it sounds weird, but you can watch him in this movie and see for yourself. The music is great. Very submerged, but it draws you in. The visual shots and everything are all just so perfect. This is why many reviewers call this a perfect movie. This is the most ambitious Coen brothers movie ever I believe. Everything just looks so real and plain as day. This is why I would come back to watch this movie. But, the blatant violence and the fact that the film is so dark in it's tone and message, makes it hard to watch for me.
One of the best films I have ever seen. Never gets old. It's brilliant in every way.

No Country for Old Men is as exceptional a mix of two creative talents- the Coen brothers, Joel and Ethan Coen, and author Cormac McCarthy (recent winner of the Pulitzer for The Road, his own masterpiece) as one could imagine, as they converge on a story that in lessor hands would be just a B movie. The story concerns an average Joe out hunting one day in Texas who comes across a bunch of dead bodies, heroin, and a satchel with 2 million in cash. He takes it, but without knowing that a true embodiment of a psychopath (Javier Bardem) is on his trail, and as he evades him it becomes more and more clear the fatalism that lies in store, as a weathered sheriff (Tommy Lee Jones) is also on the trail with perpetulally sad eyes looking on from his stolid demeanor.
Good vs Evil.  Keeps you on the edge of your seat.

3D: Deep, dark and disturbing

But we like these kinds of movies, don't we? How can I write a review without spoilers?  I'm not sure yet. I can't say enough about the actors and the characters they played. All were superb.

The storyline was not hard to follow at first, but as the movie went on, you had to realise that time kind of accellerates the more you head for the end. And you are left with some questions, but maybe they are not so important after all. For instance, how were the Mexican drug dealers able to follow the money? It's a sideline to the main plot so maybe not so important. Sometimes you have to give the author some leeway because how they able to follow it isn't that important to the main plot. Not really.

The antagonist is not necessarily one persona in this movie. It is greed and evil and heartlessness. There is more than one protagonist as well. Perhaps opportunity, hope and helplessness.  I had to watch this a few times to discover all that I could. I wonder if reading the book might help. I just might buy the book to find out.

One line sticks out to me, towards the beginning where Moss asks the dying Mexican drug-dealer, "Where's the last man? The last man standing? There always is one. Where did he go?"  Remembering this line at the end helped me tie up a few loose ends. A story well written won't give you all of the answers. A good movie well done will force you to make some determinations of your own, too.

The last scene is extremely powerful (no spoilers, I hope), the retired sheriff telling of two dreams. The first one, "Dad and I were in town and he gave me some money. I think I lost it." Dreams, and remembering them are often fleeting. And how your own brain comes up with all that stuff for you to interpret is almost always beyond me. I don't know how or why my brain comes up with such nightly movies. But I spend time trying to figure them out. There must be some reason.

Perhaps it has to do with fear, or things you can't help but try to avoid. I'm not sure.

I'll leave the second dream alone. It is certainly open to interpretation. I came up with a couple.

But this movie is gripping, well directed, acted and the cinematography is excellent.  I hate to make comparisons, and shouldn't now, but I'm reminded of how Alfred Hitchcock made films that just rocked your judgement of people and events and left you shaken. This movie does something like that, but a little differently as Hitchcock demanded more from your imagination because there were some things he couldn't put on screen to see. Over the years, the rules have changed. You can do a little more these days in movies.

I give this movie 4-1/2 stars. However, I recommend that you do not watch it late at night unless your dreaming isn't so influenced by movies of this genre.

Highly recommend. Excellent thriller/drama. This is one of the best since Fargo that the Coen brothers have directed. My only gripe is that the ending is confusing and stops abruptly, otherwise I would have given it (5) stars.

The characters did better when they had others in the scene to interact with because then you could see their line of thinking etc. Sadly that happened rarely. Everyone said there was humor in it, I couldn't find it dark or otherwise. The 'hero' is extremely smart but does one thing that overwhelmingly, unforgivably stupid and that is the thing the whole movie hinges on. He finds a drug deal gone wrong in the desert. One person is gut shot, rapidly dying asking for water. So he waits until night time to comeback with some water. Even though it's obvious the guy is already dead. Even though it's obvious the drug runners will have staked out the place. Even though nighttime is the absolute worst time to do anything. SPOILER ALERT. HOWEVER he does this anyways and of course he gets found out, followed and eventually killed.

My review will be short and sweet, contrary to the film itself. This is unquestionably one of the Coen Brothers finest films, and one of the finest films in the history of cinema. After my initial viewing years ago I thought to myself 'It's a perfect film'. After watching the film many times, nothing has changed my perspective. No Country for Old Men is a rigorously faithful adaption of the McCarthy's novel to the extent that the dialogue matches 1-to-1 to the novel in parts. I thought in the parts where the Coen brother's did take artistic license, it was with good and meaningful purpose and did nothing to alter or distort the written work in any way, shape or form.
  The film is old enough now to where it's been discussed to death, so the only thing I will mention is the purity and beauty of the landscape in which the film takes place. Like other beautiful works of art (think The Wire), the surroundings is a character unto itself. Fulfilling, surrounding and enhancing (almost comforting) the work as a whole. The violence is measured and meaningful, by no means gratuitous. Every character, even the brief cameos and appearances are in sync with the work and no appearance seems out of place or extraneous.
  In sum, as I said before, I regard this work as a perfect film. Something I don't think we will experienced in many years before No Country for Old Men, and something I don't think we will see for a long time after No Country for Old Men. It's almost a film you wish you could forget every time you see it so you could experience it again and again for the very first time.

For going on four decades, the Coen Brothers have produced films which lie slightly outside mainstream American films. Their offerings are more akin to the lower-budget film noir of the 1930s' to 1950's than the higher-budget franchise films financed by the larger corporations. Coen Brothers' trademarks include amoral, immoral and fringe-of-society characters, less-than-ideal settings, moody atmosphere, and of course violence. You could never imagine someone like Steven Spielberg directing any of the subjects chosen by the Coen Brothers. For many years, their films were generally dismissed by the Hollywood mainstream establishment as being low budget fair only for shock value, until they made "Fargo" whose female lead won the Academy Award for Best Actress. Ten years later, they made their modern noir masterpiece: "No Country for Old Men" based on the novel by Cormac McCarthy.

The artistic fusion of a Cormac McCarthy novel with the filmmaking of the Coen Brothers was a perfect match. McCarthy is an unconventional novelist whose books simultaneously straddle and challenge conventional genre fiction and high literature. Like the Coen Brothers, McCarthy subjects are not for the feint-of-heart: drug rings, the slaughter of Native Americans, and other un-Disney-type subjects. "No Country for Old Men" may be McCarthy's best use of genre fiction conventions in a literary novel. Since the Coen Brothers style is similar to McCarthy, both adhering to and breaking genre conventions, the natural pairing of these parties almost seems a bit late! However, the novel was published in 2005, and the film was released in 2007. No question, this was the perfect novel for the Coen's to produce.

"No Country for Old Men" is a combination modern western, film noir, and suspense thriller. The story unfolds rather non-linearly. Llewelyn Moss (Josh Brolin) decides to do some game hunting in an isolated area of West Texas. While pursuing pronghorn (a kind of deer-like animal), he happens upon the remains of a massacre. Dead bodies and debris are everywhere. Like a detective, he examines the remains, the cars, the bullet-holes, and the debris. This was some kind of illegal drug transaction gone awry. He also finds a Mexican dying of thirst and wounds in a pick-up truck and a case full of millions in cash. He returns that night only to find the Mexican dead and some out-for-blood baddies after him. They seem to know he took the money.

After a long chase, he finally returns home. But soon he realizes he's being stalked by perhaps the most ruthless and monstrous baddie in film history: Anton Chigurh, played with understated menace by Javier Bardem in an Academy Award-winning performance. Chigurh makes the likes of the Joker, Darth Vader and Hannibal Lecter seem closer to cultured gentlemen. What makes Chigurh and his performance by Bardem so simultaneously compelling and terrifying is his calculated coolness. He even politely asks his victims to do seeming mundane things in order to do them in. Occasionally he offers his victims a 50-50 chance of surviving with the toss of a coin. Sometimes they live, more often they die. The film becomes a terrifying cat-and-mouse game, where Chigurh is more like a serial killer cat and Moss is a mouse with millions of dollars but not the know-how to evade Chigurh. Investigating the case is Ed Tom Bell (Tommy Lee Jones) who finds bits and pieces of the puzzle, trying desperately to put it all together.

A masterpiece of modern film noir but definitely not for all tastes. In true Coen Brothers/McCarthy style, nothing is as it seems. Just when you believe all may be right with the world, the story throws a curve, and you're on another cinematic wild goose chase. You can tell the story is moving to a cataclysmic end.

"No Country for Old Men" is a vivid tale of terror and violence in the Texas heartland,  and a masterpiece of cinema from co-writers and directors Joel and Ethan Coen. It stars Josh Brolin, Tommy Lee Jones, Javier Bardem, Kelly MacDonald, and Woody Harrelson.

Llewellyn Moss (Brolin), a small-town ne'er-do-well, stumbles upon a scene of slaughter in the Texas desert - an obvious illegal drug buy gone sour. Moss finds a briefcase with two million dollars cash and decides to keep it. Soon he and his domestic partner (MacDonald) are on the run from , among others, a mysterious hit man named Anton Chigurh (Bardem), whose unique method of murder is already terrorizing the Texas heartland. Meanwhile, a dogged county sheriff (Tommy Lee Jones) tries to piece the puzzle together...

 "No Country for Old Men" garnered Academy Awards in 2007 for Best Picture, Best Director (Coen brothers), Best Original Screenplay (Coen brothers), and Best Supporting Actor (Javier Bardem). This violent, frequently bloody, and very intense film not only kept me on the edge of my seat throughout its 2-hour run time;  it kept me awake at night thinking about it. It is storytelling at its very best.  Most highly recommended.

I was expecting something a little more cerebral - or chaotic.  Neither came to fruition.  I'm not sure what the gist of the movie was, really; there's one guy who's after some money, obviously drug-related; zero character-development - and no resolution, neither at the end nor during.  Nonplussed would be the word for it.

This is old school movie making.  It harkens back to the days of very grim Western story telling.  This movie does not spoon feed the viewer too many details.  Instead, this is a story for intelligent cinema fans who don't need bantering characters who find it necessary to "casually" point out every detail.  At times, the dialogue is non-existent.  The cinematography and action speak volumes.  The soundtrack is minimal, giving the performance entirely to the scenery and the actors, also adding a desperate feel to the telling of the story.  It is a desperate one at that.  All that being said, this is a total dude movie (not to say that a woman won't enjoy it).  If you are a fan of Lone Wolf McQuade, Mad Max, The Terminator, or any other well made "movie for guys who like movies", this is a class act and a perfection of the style.  This is the guy movie that every guy movie strives to and usually falls short to be.

Okay, ya gotta wonder whether Lewellyn's wife was killed or not, don't ya? And who got the money? The title is obvious, though. What is happening in the country is so psychotic that it defies description. One thing is that I don't think the tracker in the money bag could possibly be strong enough to trace as far as the druggers did. It tells it like it is baby! Those drug lords south of the border are nothing to mess with. Ruthless, with absolutely no morals. Even today, as the president of Mexico vows to avenge the death of the massacre of many students who dared to stand against the cartel, this movie should cause any American living close to the border to be very vigilant on the home front. With an extremely porous border, and lax immigration policy, this movie is an example of the low priority given to secure the liberties of the American citizen. Now, it's ok for non-citizens to be "ok" with staying here. Many of the latinos who come here do so because their countries are so rife with corruption. They want a better life for their children. Well, just because they escaped the squalor of the barrios by getting knocked up and having a babies in the USA, does NOT entitle them to a free pass to citizenship. If there's anyone left in Mexico or Central America, would the last person please turn off the light. That is, if you have electricity.

Rare is a film as arid and windswept as the Coen Brother's No Country for Old Men. The Coens emphasize the constant breeze and brown West Texas landscape, allowing the wind to rumble through scenes in lieu of a score. The setting is as a land void of vegetation and life, requiring tough and hardscrabble inhabitants. Sheriff Ed Tom Bell (Tommy Lee Jones) embodies this life. A tanned old cuss with a Texas twang, his perspective is the subjective experience of the film. His inability to comprehend the events depicted is an entry point for viewers.

Joel and Ethan Coen's screenplay is a literate, faithful adaptation of Cormac McCarthy's 2005 novel. The story is about the pursuit of a metal suitcase full of money that Llewelyn Moss (Josh Brolin) finds while hunting. The money is from a drug deal gone wrong, and both parties involved in the transaction dispatch emissaries to find it. Anton Chigurh (Javier Bardem) is a bounty hunter with a bowl haircut and a torturous assembly of weapons designed for efficient maiming. He is an immortal evil, lurking and killing without remorse. For him, life is as arbitrary as a flip of a coin. Chigurh is a principled character whose ideals transcend money, but defy comprehension. His hunt for the Moss and the money drives the plot. Bardem won a deserved Oscar for his portrayal. Meanwhile, Sherriff Bell investigates the crimes, and searches for Moss and Chigurh. He is competent, but is unable to make sense of what he has seen.

No Country's plot articulates contemporary societal anxieties. It is set in 1979, not long before an increase in violence and the drug wars. Brolin plays Moss with decency; he is a Vietnam veteran with guile and survival instincts, but he is no match for Chigurh and the forces that pursue him.

While the plot's driver is the search for the money, an inability to make sense of the action is as important as who keeps the money. No Country for Old Men is difficult viewing, as this a story without a traditional arc, a story with arbitrary and capricious judgments. Death in the film is immediate, and final. However, the film excels in accomplishing what it sets out to do. Note how a scene near the end gives to the anti-hero a visual grammar normally reserved for the hero. Listen carefully to Sheriff Bell's opening soliloquy, as it is key to understanding the film:  "I don't want to push my chips forward and go out and meet something I don't understand. A man would have to put his soul at hazard. He'd have to say, Okay, I'll be part of this world."

Broadly, the film depicts the once peaceful, wide-open spaces of the American south west, now co-opted by violent drug dealers for their own insidious purposes and how modern-day law-enforcement has had to uncomfortably adjust. Long-time sheriff Ed Tom Bell, understanding the vicissitude of crime, reminisces fondly of the days when it was practically optional for a peace officer to even carry a gun.

The films main characters play a part in the recent criminal zeitgeist in the south west and are emblematic of: the current state of law enforcement, random drug violence, and your average citizens blinded by easy money. The story centers around Llewelyn Moss, a goodhearted resident who stumbles across a drug deal gone wrong and a large sum of money while hunting near the Rio Grande river. In a momentary lapse of impulsive greed, he takes the cash home with him. However, on a whim, returns to the gruesome scene to bring a dying man some water and is spotted by the ruthless thugs back to reclaim their money. He barely escapes but is now pursued by Anton Chigurh, a cunning, violent force of nature dedicated to his principles of murder.  sheriff Ed Tom Bell, familiar with the stalkers steadfast brutality, tries in vain to convince the prideful Moss to turn himself in, even appealing to his girlfriend for help, as he follows Chigurh's bloody killing spree.

It's an excellent depiction of a broad-category condensed into a pretty basic story. I haven't seen it yet, but I've heard amazing things about the how the desert scenery and even the gore and wounds look in HD.

This movie received an academy award and it certainly deserved it!  This movie presents its message concerning the cyclical nature of societal degradation in the trappings of a suspenseful and entertaining story.  Here the introduction of crime associated with the drug trade in rural Texas is compared to the previous lawlessness of the wild west.  I would imagine that this movie would appeal to a wide spectrum of viewers. Casual viewers will likely appreciate the action and suspense while more critical and sophisticated viewers will praise its frequent and well-placed use of symbolism and metaphor to compliment the story and its message.  This movie greatly rewards those who unlock its secrets!

There is a strong permeating feeling of permanence in No Country For Old Men. Of something preordained and unchangeable. Not like fate, far from that. Something perpetual that operates freely and without mercy. Flowing invariably, remarkably so. The haunts of our lives, the guardians of myth. What becomes of constants?

The central themes of No Country For Old Men are those of male impotence, generational emasculation, and death. These themes are surprisingly easy to recognize and examine. Death is the most simple theme to pinpoint and work off of because it is given an actual flesh and blood form. Death as personified by Anton Chigurh. The modern day grim reaper, the prophet of chance, and the symbol of inescapable destiny. Portrayed incredibly by Javier Bardem in an Oscar winning performance, Chigurh secures a place in the hall of legends for his villainy and precision. Bardem effortlessly lays down one of the best performances of all time. What Bardem does with Chigurh should be studied fiercely by all appreciators of high art.

Death haunts, hunts, and death never fails. Questing, Chigurh is nomadic, a sprawling landscape onto himself -- the essence of wandering purpose. Chigurh goes above and beyond mere competence, he grazes the terrain of perfection. A blessed performance. One of the most amazing I have ever seen. Of nuance and amplified myth. So far as No Country is concerned, death is inexorable by nature and merciless by design. Death is evil by decision, by intent, and by chance. Death is coming.

The theme of generational emasculation is represented by the character of Sheriff Bell, as portrayed with great discipline and frailty by Tommy Lee Jones. Being an old man, it is perhaps Bell whom the film's title refers to. It would certainly make the most sense. Generational emasculation remains a great fear for old men, dwarfed only by death. The older one gets, the less connected to the world he feels and the less in tune with it he gradually becomes. The older one gets, the less in touch with the modern definition of manliness they are, clinging fruitlessly to those ascribed to the dead of the past. Masculinity is lost in the changing tides of bygone eras and newfound sensibilities. Where once the country was theirs, the terrain ripe for rugged settlement, where golden mountains and silver streams flowed in their name, the songbirds of fertility swooned and flapped their wings with high-yeilding prospect and love. Now their country has dried up. It is no longer theirs and no longer associated with them. There truly is no country for them, no where that is safe from the ever-changing world.

Male impotence. Llewelyn Moss, a guarded performance by Josh Brolin. Men can no longer protect themselves. Men can no longer comfort nor protect their women. Men can no longer defend against anything, long gone are the stoic soldiers of stone and marble. Men are hapless, helpless, arrogant, and wrong. Fatal flaws enacted through human means and necessities. Moss clearly is representative of the film's most chilling theme: inescapable male impotence. As a gender, manhood is a dying and lost cause. The film can even be viewed as the death of masculinity in the contemporary society. Time and country has made men of a certain practice and likeness endangered, natural selection has placed them upon the sacrificial altar of the changing tides. And death has been appointed to carry out the extermination. No Country For Old Men is about the extinction of all men. Of the the idea of men. Of defined masculinity and male freedom and of leadership and other now-archaic characteristics of the lost sex. All generations of men eventually become extinct. There is no place in the world for their kind. There never really was. They leased their world, each subsequent generation paying rent for their transitory universe. But now it's certainty through impermanence that defines our tide, not likelihood in survival.

Not fate. Not chance. Just certainty.

Skillfully and thoughtfully directed by the Coen brothers, No Country For Old Men is a film that will live forever in the hearts and minds of every man who ever experiences it. It is a brilliant film and it is a masterpiece of the highest order.

I first want to say that there will be spoilers ahead.

In No Country for Old Men, based off of the novel by Cormac McCarthy, we follow the stories of a hunter (Josh Brolin) a psychopathic killer (Javier Bardem), a hired hand (Woody Harrelson), and an almost retired cop, (Tommy Lee Jones).
All four of their stories eventually collide into what we call a disaster.
Before I go on, I just want to say that this movie should definitely be confined to a more mature audience, as there is language, a couple suggestive themes, and gritty, non-sugarcoated, action.

Now, I would give this movie five stars for these reasons: I liked it that they didn't sugarcoat the fact that evil is not always destroyed. So many times in both movies and books, its always the same theme over and over. The good guys win after a hard battle, and evil is vanquished forever. But I personally believe that that's unrealistic, the fact is, evil will never be completely destroyed. I also enjoyed the way the plot unfolded to include a simple hunter and a retired cop against a hired hand and a whacko. The action was realistic, and in the scene where Javier Bardem gets shot by Josh Brolin in the leg, for once that blood looked real.
There were many good scenes in this movie, but every movie has its flaws as well.
One part I did not agree with was when Tommy Lee Jones says "I asked for God to come into my life, well guess what, he didn't." That to me sounded like something added to make God seem like the villain. But the second part of his phrase, "Well, if that's his opinion of me, I certainly deserve it. I don't blame him for it." Was totally true.
This movie was troubling and exciting, clear cut and suspenseful, and will definitely leave you thinking long after the credits pop up on the screen.
This movie has a mixed message, but I would definitely recommend to anyone who enjoys a movie that makes you think, or even if you enjoy non-stop bloody action, then this one is for you.

  Yours truly,

  ~A reviewer.

So, I LOVE The Last of Us (By Neil Druckmann and Bruce Straley of Naughty Dog). It depicts a grisly post-pandemic world where people are now out for survival, and will do anything to keep those they love surviving with them. What does this have to do with No Country for Old Men?
Well, Mr. Druckmann, in an interview(s), stated that this movie was a key influence in their story. So, with me loving The Last of Us and attempting to create stories, too, i asked my parents to check this out (Yeah, i'm probably not officially allowed to view this, but anyway)....

The plot centers around a protagonist, Llewellyn Moss (Josh Brolin), a retired veteran and welder - and an antagonist, Anton Chigurh (Javier Bardem), a psychopathic killer being hunted by the police.

Llewellyn Moss, while hunting, stumbles across a crime scene. A drug deal that went south. Bodies lie everywhere. Abandoned bullet-ridden cars stand here and there. And a case full of money... millions of dollars... lies out in the open for the taking. So Llewellyn takes it, thinking he's rich, and goes home. What he doesn't realize is that Chigurh wants the money, too... and will stop at nothing to get it, even if that means killing people right and left to do so.
So the chase is on... Llewellyn runs for his life, telling his wife to be safe.... Chigurh begins hunting him, leaving a massacre in his path.... and the Sheriff (the Old Man in the title played by Tommy Lee Jones)... seeks to bring Chigurh to justice, and is depressed by his obstacles.

Before i continue, let me state that i prefer realistic movies to sugar-coated ones, no matter how bloody or troubling it has to be. Got it? Good. Let's move on...

Right from the bat, the film took me in. The moment Chigurh begins his killing spree, and Llewellyn Moss finds the money. The suspense is constant throughout the film, all the way until the conclusion (more on that later). You feel it every moment Chigurh searches out Moss. You know that the moment Chigurh find him, Moss is toast. It's clear in the way the killer slaughters everyone in his path. Either to get a car so he can travel faster or because he mistook some people as his target. And he never shows remorse. Never seems to flinch. With a nod to DC comics, he even (sometimes) uses one of the major villains trademarks to decide whether to kill or not.
You ever seen a movie where your thinking to yourself, "no, No, NO! Don't Just stand there! Move!"?
Well, I've never experienced that until this. I never understood why i'd feel that way. But now it is crystal clear. It's because of the stakes, and the realness of the threat.
Though set in old 60s Texas... a Texas with civilization still around and working... SURVIVAL (like in The Last of Us) is riddled throughout the narrative. Even more so than most post-apocalyptic survival movies I've seen: Being creative with the tools at hand. Using distractions. Dealing with wounds. Checking one's surroundings. Being aware. Thinking ahead. All of it is done realistically, in a way that descends to a human level, rather than ascending to the superhero Jason Bourne or Jack Reacher where everyone is an assassin with martial arts and CIA training. The story comes down to how a normal human can be strategic and live when something is out to kill you, whether it be a killer... or dreadful Infected humans or other survivors. NCFOM dealt with this superbly, and Neil wisely took note of this style and made his creation THAT much more perfect. I will probably do the same with my stories.
The fights are gritty, real, and tension-filled... as are the consequences. Unlike a lot of films where the violence is done in such a way that you are grinning and whooping, enjoying the battles... here you squirm and shudder. This is how it really is. It isn't enjoyable or a fun. IT is scary. And the characters know that (except the insane killer, of course).
 All the characters, both good and bad, respond to their circumstances the way their personalities would in real life. Moss is scared and doesn't understand everything like a super spy or secret CIA agent would (films like to make us believe they do). He is just a normal vet running for his life. And Chigurh.... he is a killer, without guilt, without sanity, and he doesn't need any evil laugh, monologues, or a villainous costume to get the point across.... and he doesn't attempt to sugar-coat his doings for the sake of the audience (which i love - not in the literal sense of the word). He does what any demonically insane person would do, and Bardem is fantastic all the way. Kudos to the actor for his performance. I genuinely hated his character, and even found myself hoping that Moss would end him. That takes real acting for a guy to get the audience to both FEAR (yes, i feared him) and hate his character. Of this entire FANTASTIC cast, Bardem is the leader.

But what makes the film "epic", so to speak, isn't the fights and tension by themselves, but in addition to the mirrors it sets up against real life. People complained that Tommy Lee Jones' character didn't serve a purpose, and it is true... the Sheriff never actually does much to the overall plot. But he is the one who gets the message across and comes out with the big realization (character development, possibly). Whereas Brolin and Bardem fill up the screen with the action (both fighting and suspense)... Jones deals with the themes (some of them). As a cop, he is depressed and feels hopeless. He sees the world as it really is: A dangerous place with wicked people. A world that is getting worse and worse. He hates that he cannot stop evil from happening, that no matter what he does, no matter how hard he tries, he can't prevent terrible things. Evil DOES get away. Good does perish. This movie reflects that. THAT's the real world, and the Coen Bros didn't try to sugar-coat it.
It also reminds the viewers that THEY are responsible for their own actions. Even if you don't feel guilty (like Chigurh), even if you try to put the responsibility on someone else or SOMETHING else, everything you do is your choice, and you are responsible. We do feel guilt, and we know what is right. Moss knows what's right, and doing the right thing helped get him into more trouble. Doing the right thing doesn't mean it is the easiest or the most rewarding. Oftentimes, bad people get away with their actions, and the good are left bleeding. But we should do what we know is right, always, even if the outcome might be grisly. We can't let our humanity disappear like Chigurh's. Do the wrong thing, and though you may get away with it for a while (even most of your life) it will always come back around.
The ending was somewhat iffy, I'll admit... and the only real thing i had against the film. The gore wasn't an issue, because it was needed in the context of the story to drive home the depths to which Chigurh's humanity had fallen. Cussing is never an issue. And sexuality is nil. But the ending felt... like it just stopped. That is what, superficially, it looks like. But that's because, IMO, the story's message was played out within the middle. There is no epilogue. It does leave you hanging, because it wants you to think about everything else. Or, should i say, the Coen Brothers wanted you to think on everything else.

Neil Druckmann was right. This is definitely a five star, thought-provoking film... and now i see why it so influenced The Last of Us. Though the messages are different, both stories focus on a lot of the same things. Survival. Humanity. Tension. Death. You name it. And if there's any question as to whether we should keep guns, this movie is your answer. The people of the USA need to be able to defend themselves AND mind their surroundings. Common sense first, then a weapon to defend yourselves. You never know who could be prowling about.

Just remember, you need more than the door's lock to keep yourself safe in a room. Remember that.

This is an astoundingly riveting film that ends in mid-story with no satisfying resolution. When I saw it on a movie channel recently I thought they cut off the end so they could run HUNT FOR RED OCTOBER on time. Only later did I find that what I'd seen was, in fact, the end...as if the production had simply run out of film and money. Then I learned it was a Cohen Brothers film and I've yet to see a satisfying film by them. They have talent, just no perceivable attention span. That said, the movie was enormously entertaining while it lasted. I hope some day someone will finish the story. The least the evil cartel hit man could have done is kill the two kids at the end. They did, after all, see him.

The movie was cast very well, the script was extraordinary, the acting first rate. The direction was mostly excellent EXCEPT that most seasoned cops wouldn't have stood in an empty doorway holding a gun and facing into a darkened hotel room, perfectly backlit, like the sheriff did in the end. And most seasoned sheriffs probably would have had the milk bottle checked for prints before pouring himself some milk from the same bottle. Finally, most seasoned professional assassins wouldn't leave their fingerprints spread so promiscuously around the places our bad guy ("Sugar") did while he was looking for the money. Still, what do a couple of young Yankee Jewish kids know about such things? That was a nice shot of Tommy Lee Jones standing silhouetted against the lights outside, his handgun held at the ready. (Had anyone been in that darkened room with a gun...even a .22LR pistol...the last thing Tommy Lee would have seen was the muzzleflashes before the bullets slammed into his body. I'm sure their were a lot of trained law enforcement types who cringed at these parts of the movie.)

I reckon the point of the film is that bad people do bad things and no one can stop them, no matter how many generations come and go. Even Sugar doesn't make it out unscathed. For all his belief in fate, he nearly gets killed in an automobile accident while distracted by two kids on bikes.
